Reviews.title: The motivation of the problem is not clear
Reviews.review:
1) Motivation of the problem is not very clear: It seems like the aim is classify impulse noise types and if they originate from the top, bottom or same floor. What is not clear, however, is the usefulness of collecting the test and train data from the same building. Shouldn't the test and train data be from mutually exclusive buildings?
2) It is also not clear whether the datasets were collected from one or many buildings
3) The authors should also provide an intuitive explanation why the sounds from the three floors would sound different. And is this specific to a particular building or can be generalized across buildings? Would the size and contents of the rooms (e.g, carpets, furnitures) have an impact on the accuracy?
Reviews.rating: 4: Ok but not good enough - rejection
Reviews.confidence: 2: The reviewer is willing to defend the evaluation, but it is quite likely that the reviewer did not understand central parts of the paper

Reviews.title: Novel application area but lacking in novelty in modeling technique.
Reviews.review:
This work describes the use of convolutional neural networks in a novel application area of building noise type classification and noise position classification. The paper describes the motivation, dataset and the evaluation in great detail . However the modeling techniques being used are lacking in originality.
The paper is unique and interesting but this conference might not be the most appropriate one for this publication.
Reviews.rating: 4: Ok but not good enough - rejection
Reviews.confidence: 4: The reviewer is confident but not absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct

Reviews.title: An interesting application of CNN for classification on audio dataset.
Reviews.review:
The paper applied convolution neural network for type/position classification tasks on an interesting audio dataset which recorded the impact noises of a building. Details description of the dataset is provided and experiment results with VGG16 are presented. All in all, while the application scenario is interesting, the novelty of the paper is rather mild. Using pretrain VGG for audio classification has already been proposed by several other papers.  Moreover, this paper may receive a much broader audience in acoustic journal/conference than in ICLR.

Several improvements can be done for the papers. Firstly, an embedding layer or a transformation layer can be built for transforming the audio signals into “images”. It would be interesting to compare this type of structure versus directly using log-scaled Mel-spectrogram. Second, instead of using images to pre-train VGG network. How about using acoustic signals. What can be the gain or loss of the performance?  Third, more detail information about the adaptation layer can be provided. Fourth, about the metric used for position prediction, it would be nice to have a weighted accuracy with the consideration of position.
Reviews.rating: 4: Ok but not good enough - rejection
Reviews.confidence: 4: The reviewer is confident but not absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct
